description: A broad term for music produced in, or rooted in the traditions of, Western art music, encompassing a wide historical period from roughly the 11th century to the present day. It is characterized by its formal structures, complex harmonies, and instrumental virtuosity.

subgenres.name: Baroque (c. 1600–1750)
subgenres.description: Characterized by grand, dramatic, and energetic spirit, and a focus on counterpoint, ornamentation, and the basso continuo.

subgenres.name: Classical Period (c. 1750–1820)
subgenres.description: Emphasizes clarity, balance, and formal structure. The symphony, concerto, and sonata forms were fully developed during this era.

subgenres.name: Romantic (c. 1800–1910)
subgenres.description: Focused on emotional expression, individualism, and nationalism. Music became more dramatic, lyrical, and rich in harmony.

subgenres.name: Opera
subgenres.description: A theatrical art form where singers and musicians perform a dramatic work combining text (libretto) and musical score.

subgenres.name: Symphony
subgenres.description: An extended musical composition for orchestra, typically in four movements, at least one of which is traditionally in sonata form.
key_works: Dvořák's Symphony No. 9 'From the New World'

subgenres.name: 20th Century & Modern
subgenres.description: A period of diverse styles, including impressionism, expressionism, neoclassicism, and serialism, often breaking away from traditional tonality.
